awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Strain Rate and Moment Accumulation Rate along the San Andreas Fault System from InSAR and GPS
awd_abstract_narration:
The San Andreas Fault System (SAFS) is a natural laboratory for investigating the physics of the earthquake cycle along a major continental transform boundary. Two of the key parameters that can be used for seismic hazard assessment are seismic moment accumulation rate and strain accumulation rate. The GPS component of the Plate Boundary Observatory (PBO) provides accurate vector velocities (< 1 mm/yr accuracy) at a spacing of 10 to 20 km along the SAFS. However, the velocity gradient (strain rate) varies most rapidly within 20 km of the major faults, so strain rate is not well resolved by the GPS data alone. Radar interferometry (InSAR) provides deformation maps at 100 m spatial resolution, although factors such as temporal decorrelation and atmospheric path errors have made it difficult to achieve this full resolution with sufficient precision to improve upon the GPS measurements. The L-band data provided by the ALOS satellite (JAXA) retains phase coherence over longer time intervals than the prior C-band missions. This improvement, combined with stacking techniques to reduce atmospheric errors, now makes it possible to image the entire SAFS using InSAR with unprecedented spatial coverage and resolution.

The primary focus of this research is to construct high spatial resolution vector surface deformation measurements by combining the high accuracy point measurements provided by PBO GPS data with the high spatial resolution InSAR measurements available through WInSAR from foreign and domestic SAR missions. The research has four main objectives:

- Resolve secular plate boundary deformation using new GPS and InSAR measurements provided by EarthScope (PBO and WInSAR). This involves the development of community software to preprocess the new data streams to be provided by the ALOS-2 and Sentinel-1 InSAR satellites (2013 launch);
- Use an integrated GPS-4D model-InSAR technique to better constrain fault slip rates and determine the depth of the locked/creeping transition on active faults of the SAFS;
- Generate high-resolution estimates of strain rate and seismic moment rate along major faults of the SAFS; and
- Explore methods for isolating non-tectonic deformation contributions common in both InSAR and GPS data.

Non-technical summary

Is California prepared for the next big earthquake? Estimates of earthquake potential along major faults, such as the San Andreas Fault System (SAFS), are used for developing scenario earthquakes, for setting regional building codes, and for setting earthquake insurance rates. While the timing of a major earthquake cannot be accurately predicted, the moment magnitude can be accurately estimated from geodetic measurements of present-day crustal deformation. The current array of 700 continuously operating GPS stations in western North America does not completely resolve the crustal deformation gradients (strain) along the major faults because the average station spacing is too large. This research is refining the crustal deformation measurements by computing and modeling the synthetic aperture radar data (SAR) archived at the Western North America InSAR consortium (WInSAR) and the Alaska Satellite Facility. This involves the generation and archive of large-scale (1000 km scale) crustal deformation grids at 0.5 km spatial resolution in a near-automatic fashion. Funding from this grant is supporting two Ph.D. students at SIO and UTEP (a Hispanic Serving Institute) and is being used for further development of undergraduate and graduate courses. This funding is also being used to develop a ?How InSAR Works? module for use in IRISʼs Active Earth interactive kiosks on display around the country. In addition, funding is being used to move the GMTSAR software into the GMT distribution system where it is available to 15,000 users worldwide. We are distributing all high-resolution vector deformation data and maps to the scientific community and archive the results at UNAVCO.

por.por_cntn:
Collaborative Research: Strain Rate and Moment Accumulation Rate along the San Andreas Fault System from InSAR and GPS

 

Summary:  The absence of a major earthquake along the San Andreas Fault System (SAFS) over the past 110 years, a region home to over 10 million people, provides ample motivation for studying the loading conditions of this active plate boundary (Figure 1). While the timing of the next major earthquake is largely unpredictable, the earthquake potential along all of the faults can be accurately estimated by measuring the seismic moment accumulation rate. The moment accumulation rate multiplied by the time since the last major rupture is a direct measure of potential earthquake magnitude.  The two measurement systems we use are the Global Positioning System (GPS), which can monitor the crustal velocity across the faults to an accuracy of a few mm/yr, and radar interferometry (InSAR) which has lower accuracy than GPS but provides a complete map of surface velocity. 

 

We proposed the following tasks:

- Measure plate boundary velocity using GPS and InSAR data provided by EarthScope.

- Use these data to develop a 3D, time-dependent model of fault slip rates and determine the depth of the locked/creeping transition on active faults of the SAFS.

- Generate high-resolution estimates of strain rate and seismic moment rate along major faults of the SAFS.

- Explore methods for isolating non-tectonic deformation contributions common in both InSAR and GPS data.

 

Our results are provided in 6 peer-reviewed publications (and 1 currently in review) and the InSAR software development is available at http://topex.ucsd.edu/gmtsar.  Major outcomes follow:

1) A complete crustal velocity map of the SAFS shown in Figures 3-5 and published in the Journal of Geophysical Research [Tong et al., 2013].

2) A physical model of the surface velocity that provides slip rates and moment accumulation rates along each fault. We found that the slip rates from the space geodetic data are in accordance with the geological estimates of slip rate [Tong et al., 2014].  In addition we found that parts of the “creeping section” of the SAFS are partly locked and are accumulating seismic moment [Tong et al., 2015].

3) We used this model to better understand the vertical motions along the SAFS and see long-term vertical motions in 100-year coastal tide gauge records [Smith-Konter et al., 2014] as well as the shorter-term motions from the more widespread GPS data [Howell et al., 2016] (Figure 2).  

4) We analyzed regional well log data from the California Department of Water Resources to better understand non-tectonic deformation contributions common in both InSAR and PBO GPS data (Figure 6). 

5) Finally, we developed new software to advance our studies of crustal deformation and moment accumulation.   These new additions to our computer code were documented in Sandwell and Smith-Konter [2017].

 

The intellectual merit of this investigation was to obtain an improved understanding of the crustal loading and release processes associated with the earthquake cycle.  The broader impacts of this investigation are to estimate the earthquake potential of the faults along the SAFs as well as to train the next generation of science and technical leaders.   We also leveraged our expertise in development of IRIS Active Earth Monitor (AEM) displays, assisting two local Honolulu schools with the installation of their own library AEM kiosks.

 

Publications*:

 *underline denotes student authorship

Sandwell, D.T. and B. Smith-Konter, Maxwell:  A semi-analytic 4-D code for earthquake cycle modeling of transform fault systems, submitted to Computers and Geosciences.

 Howell, S., B. Smith-Konter, N. Fraizer, X. Tong, and D.T. Sandwell (2016), The vertical fingerprint of earthquake-cycle loading in Southern California, Nature Geosciences, doi: 10.1093/2015-03-04591.

 Tong, X., D.T. Sandwell, and B. Smith-Konter (2015), An integral method to estimate the moment accumulation rate on the Creeping Section of the San Andreas Fault, Geophys. Jour. Int., doi: 10.1093/gji/gjis140783.

 Tong, X., B. Smith-Konter, and D.T. Sandwell (2014), A new viscoelastic earthquake cycle model may explain discrepancies in San Andreas fault slip, EOS AGU Research Spotlight, v. 95, no. 34.

 Smith-Konter, B., G.M. Thornton, and D.T. Sandwell (2014), Vertical crustal displacement due to interseismic deformation along the San Andreas fault: Constraints from tide gauges, Geophys. Res. Lett., doi:10.1029/2014GL060091.

 Tong, X., B. Smith-Konter, and D. T. Sandwell (2014) Is there a discrepancy between geological and geodetic slip rates along the San Andreas Fault System?, J. Geophys. Res., doi: 10.1002/2013JB010765.

Tong, X., D. T. Sandwell, and B. Smith-Konter (2013), High-resolution interseismic velocity data along the San Andreas Fault from GPS and InSAR, J. Geophys. Res., 118, doi:10.1029/2012JB009442.

 


Last Modified: 09/18/2017
Modified by: Bridget R Smith-Konter

Images (1 of )
  • Map of the southern San Andreas Fault System showing fault locking depth variations and historical earthquake sequence. Locked SAFS segments are represented in color to illustrate the historical earthquake sequence.
    Howell et al. [2016]
    Copyrighted
    Bridget R Smith-Konter
    Figure 1
  • GPS and physic-based model comparison. Smoothed vertical velocities observed by the GPS data closely match a physical deformation model simulating the vertical crustal response of earthquake cycle loading at depth throughout the last 300+ years.
    Howell et al. [2016]
    Bridget R Smith-Konter
    Figure 2
  • Comparison of GPS velocity data and physical deformation model estimates. (a) Model and data horizontal velocities. The black arrows show the observed GPS horizontal velocity vectors with uncertainties. The blue arrows show the predicted horizontal velocity vectors from our preferred model.
    Tong et al. [2014]
    Copyrighted
    Bridget R Smith-Konter
    Figure 3
  • Comparison of InSAR LOS velocity data and and physical deformation model estimates. Positive velocities (red) represent ground motion away from the satellite (a) Observed InSAR LOS velocity. (b) Predicted InSAR LOS velocity from the prefered model. (c) Residuals (observation - model).
    Tong et al. [2014]
    Copyrighted
    Bridget R Smith-Konter
    Figure 4
  • (a) California crustal velocity map derived from integrating GPS observations (triangles) with ALOS-1 radar interferograms (2006-2010). (b) Southern part of the SAFS shows the broad transition in velocity. (c) Central part shows a sharp velocity gradient across the creeping section.
    Tong et al. [2014]
    Copyrighted
    Bridget R Smith-Konter
    Figure 5
  • Groundwater level rates from well logs data provided by the California Department of Water Resources. Blue colors represent a decrease in ground water level over roughly the past decade, while red colors indicate an increase in ground water level over the past decade.
    A. Lee
    Public Domain
    Bridget R Smith-Konter
    Figure 6

Collaborative Research: Strain Rate and Moment Accumulation Rate along the San Andreas Fault System from InSAR and GPS

 

Summary:  The absence of a major earthquake along the San Andreas Fault System (SAFS) over the past 110 years, a region home to over 10 million people, provides ample motivation for studying the loading conditions of this active plate boundary (Figure 1). While the timing of the next major earthquake is largely unpredictable, the earthquake potential along all of the faults can be accurately estimated by measuring the seismic moment accumulation rate. The moment accumulation rate multiplied by the time since the last major rupture is a direct measure of potential earthquake magnitude.  The two measurement systems we use are the Global Positioning System (GPS), which can monitor the crustal velocity across the faults to an accuracy of a few mm/yr, and radar interferometry (InSAR) which has lower accuracy than GPS but provides a complete map of surface velocity. 

 

We proposed the following tasks:

- Measure plate boundary velocity using GPS and InSAR data provided by EarthScope.

- Use these data to develop a 3D, time-dependent model of fault slip rates and determine the depth of the locked/creeping transition on active faults of the SAFS.

- Generate high-resolution estimates of strain rate and seismic moment rate along major faults of the SAFS.

- Explore methods for isolating non-tectonic deformation contributions common in both InSAR and GPS data.

 

Our results are provided in 6 peer-reviewed publications (and 1 currently in review) and the InSAR software development is available at http://topex.ucsd.edu/gmtsar.  Major outcomes follow:

1) A complete crustal velocity map of the SAFS shown in Figures 3-5 and published in the Journal of Geophysical Research [Tong et al., 2013].

We found that the slip rates from the space geodetic data are in accordance with the geological estimates of slip rate [Tong et al., 2014]. 4) We analyzed regional well log data from the California Department of Water Resources to better understand non-tectonic deformation contributions common in both InSAR and PBO GPS data (Figure 6). 

5) Finally, we developed new software to advance our studies of crustal deformation and moment accumulation.   These new additions to our computer code were documented in Sandwell and Smith-Konter [2017].

 

The intellectual merit of this investigation was to obtain an improved understanding of the crustal loading and release processes associated with the earthquake cycle.  The broader impacts of this investigation are to estimate the earthquake potential of the faults along the SAFs as well as to train the next generation of science and technical leaders.   We also leveraged our expertise in development of IRIS Active Earth Monitor (AEM) displays, assisting two local Honolulu schools with the installation of their own library AEM kiosks.
